cfl.visualization_methods package¶

Submodules¶

cfl.visualization_methods.el_nino_vis module¶

A module for Visualization methods of CFL results Iman Wahle and Jenna Kahn Aug 28 2020

cfl.visualization_methods.el_nino_vis.visualize(X, Y, x_lbls, y_lbls, fig_kwargs=None, X_kwargs=None, Y_kwargs=None)¶

Iterate over each cluster in X and Y to plot the cluster average’s difference from the global mean. Only good for spatially organized data :param X: X dataset of dimensions [# observations, # features] (np.array) :param Y: Y dataset of dimensions [# observations, # features] (np.array) :param x_lbls: class label for each observation in X, of dimensions [# observations,] (np.array) :param y_lbls: class label for each observation in Y, of dimensions [# observations,] (np.array) :param fig_kwargs: dictionary of keyword arguments to pass to plt.figure (specify appearance of plot) :param X_kwargs: dictionary of keyword arguments to pass to visualize_helper for the X plots :param Y_kwargs: dictionary of keyword arguments to pass to visualize_helper for the Y plots

Returns: None

cfl.visualization_methods.el_nino_vis.visualize_helper(col, data, lbls, kwargs)¶

For a given variable (X or Y), plot each cluster average’s difference from the global mean. :param col: which column in the figure to assign to this variable (int) :param data: X or Y dataset of dimensions [# observations, # features] (np.array) :param lbls: cluster labels of dimensions [# observations,] (np.array) :param levels: what levels to plot on contour plot (TODO: infer this from data) :param kwargs: dictionary of keyword arguments to pass to ax.contourf (specify appearance of plot)

Returns: None

cfl.visualization_methods.general_vis module¶

cfl.visualization_methods.general_vis.view_class_examples(images, im_shape, n_examples, x_lbls)¶

shows images in matplotlib with labels displayed at the top of each image. Best for viewing a lot of images at once.

Parameters

  • images (2D or 3D np array) – Array of images (must be aligned with x_lbls) If 2D, axis 0 = samples, axis 1 = flattened image pixels If 3D, axis 0 = samples, axis 1 = image rows, axis 2 = image cols

  • n_rows (int) – Number of rows of images to display.

  • x_lbls (1D np array) – labels to show at the top of each image. Should be aligned with the images input

cfl.visualization_methods.general_vis.view_random_example(image_array, random_state=None)¶

chooses a random image from the image_array and displays it. Setting random state causes it to be reproducible

cfl.visualization_methods.visual_bars_vis module¶

cfl.visualization_methods.visual_bars_vis.viewImagesAndLabels(images, im_shape, n_examples, x_lbls)¶

shows images in matplotlib with labels displayed at the top of each image. Best for viewing a lot of images at once. Designed with visual bars images in mind.

Parameters: images (2D or 3D np array): Array of images (must be aligned with x_lbls)

If 2D, axis 0 = samples, axis 1 = flattened image pixels If 3D, axis 0 = samples, axis 1 = image rows, axis 2 = image cols

n_rows (int): Number of rows of images to display. x_lbls (1D np array): labels to show at the top of each image.

Should be aligned with the images input

cfl.visualization_methods.visual_bars_vis.viewSingleImage(image_array, random_state=None)¶

chooses a random image from the image_array and displays it. Setting random state causes it to be reproducible
